title-group.article-title: Iterative Linking With the Differential Functioning of Items and Tests (DFIT) Method
title-group.subtitle: Comparison of Testwide and Item Parameter Replication (IPR) Critical Values

author-notes.corresp: Jacob Seybert, Department of Psychology, University of South Florida, 4202 East Fowler Avenue, PCD4118G, Tampa, FL 33620-7200, USA Email: jseybert@mail.usf.edu

abstract.p: A Monte Carlo study was conducted to examine the accuracy of differential item functioning (DIF) detection using the differential functioning of items and tests (DFIT) method. Specifically, the performance of DFIT was compared using “testwide” critical values suggested by Flowers, Oshima, and Raju, based on simulations involving large numbers of DIF-free items, with item-specific critical values obtained via the newer item parameter replication (IPR) method. Also examined were the benefits of single-stage, two-stage, and iterative linking for dichotomous and ordered polytomous data involving samples of various size, tests of different length, types and percentages of DIF items, and levels of impact. Overall, the results indicated that testwide and IPR-based critical values corresponding to a nominal alpha of .01 provided similar power for detecting DIF due to shifts in extremity parameters, but IPR power was generally lower when DIF was due to differences in discrimination. In addition, IPR-based critical values provided as good as or better control of Type I error under most conditions, and results improved for all methods when using two-stage and iterative linking rather than single-stage linking and DIF analysis. The implications of these findings for future research involving the DFIT method with various item response models are discussed.

kwd-group.kwd: differential functioning of items and tests (DFIT)

body.p: With the growing emphasis on testing to assist in selection and promotion decisions and track the achievement of student learning outcomes, the issue of measurement bias remains a preeminent concern. As indicated by the Standards for Educational and Psychological Testing (American Educational Research Association, American Psychological Association, & National Council on Measurement in Education, 1999), item response theory (IRT) offers a variety of methods for testing the measurement invariance of items across subpopulations of examinees that may differ in their overall levels of proficiency or standing on the underlying trait(s) measured by a test. The expansion of testing beyond the cognitive domain into areas such as personality, facets of which predict educational achievement and health-related behaviors (Chernyshenko, Stark, Drasgow, & Roberts, 2007), signals the need for methods that can be readily implemented with dichotomous and polytomous data and are suitable for examining item and scale level invariance.

One such method that has drawn a great deal of attention in the applied psychology literature is the differential functioning of items and tests (DFIT) method (Raju, van der Linden, & Fleer, 1995). The DFIT method is capable of detecting differential item functioning (DIF), defined as a difference in the probability of correctly answering or endorsing an item after conditioning on trait level (Drasgow & Kang, 1984; Millsap & Everson, 1993), as well as differential test functioning (DTF), defined analogously as a difference in expected test or scale score functions across comparison groups. The DFIT approach has demonstrated good power and Type I error rates for DIF detection in simulation studies involving tests of various lengths and parameters estimated in samples of different size (Bolt, 2002; Meade, Lautenschlager, & Johnson, 2007; Raju, et al., 2009). However, numerous questions remain as to whether iterative linking (Candell & Drasgow, 1988) and the use of item-specific critical values obtained using the relatively new item parameter replication (IPR) method (Oshima, Raju, & Nanda, 2006; Raju, et al., 2009) can improve on the accuracy of single-stage linking and DIF detection via a “testwide” critical value (i.e., using the same critical value for all items). This study addresses these questions through a Monte Carlo simulation of dichotomous and polytomous response data exploring the accuracy of DIF detection using testwide and IPR-derived critical values under single-stage, two-stage, and iterative linking.

sec.title: DIF Detection in the DFIT Framework
sec.p: Raju et al. (1995) developed the DFIT method for dichotomous data, and it was extended to the polytomous case by Flowers, Oshima, and Raju (1999). Under this framework, parameter estimates for a focal group and a reference group are linked, and two sets of expected item scores are computed for each focal group examinee (s) using his or her trait score estimate (s) and either the focal (F) or reference (R) group item parameter estimates. Specifically, the expected score on item i for examinee s, treated as a member of group g, is given by

where k is an index for response categories 1 to m, and

i g k
(

s
)
represents the probability of choosing category k based on the item parameter estimates for group g. The difference in expected item scores under these scenarios is given by
and the noncompensatory DIF (NCDIF) index is defined as

where
μ
d i
2
and
σ
d i
2
are the mean and variance, respectively, of the differences in expected item scores among focal group examinees.

According to Raju et al. (1995), a chi-square test was originally developed for flagging DIF items, but because it proved too sensitive to sample size, alternative empirically based critical values for NCDIF detection were recommended. Specifically, values of .006, .010, .013, and .016 were suggested for tests involving items having a maximum of two, three, four, and five response categories, respectively. These “testwide” critical values were determined by simulating data for non-DIF items, computing NCDIF statistics, and finding the values above which 1% of the items were misclassified as DIF (Flowers et al., 1999). Although this approach resolved concerns about the use of chi-square tests for NCDIF detection, it did not address the issue of the generalizability of those critical values to tests involving different item parameters. Later developments of DFIT suggested a strategy for the calculation of a critical value for individual items computed based on the number of response categories, k, equal to .006(k− 1)2 (Raju, 2002). The use of testwide critical values also did not account for the possibility that response categories for extreme items might need to be collapsed in some instances for parameter estimation.

To investigate the efficacy of Raju’s testwide critical values for polytomous five-option tests, Meade et al. (2007) conducted a Monte Carlo study comparing Raju’s recommendations with critical values derived empirically for a new 12-item measure, as well as those used by Bolt (2002) and Flowers et al. (1999). Meade et al. found that their empirically derived critical values provided the highest power for NCDIF detection while controlling Type I error, which supported the notion that critical values should ideally be developed for the particular set of items examined. Yet, because it is unrealistic to expect practitioners to conduct Monte Carlo studies to determine critical values in the course of a typical DIF analysis, Meade et al. provided recommendations based on sample size and the relative costs of Type I and Type II errors.

At about the same time that other studies involving testwide critical values for NCDIF detection were beginning to appear in the literature, Oshima and colleagues (2006) proposed a method for obtaining critical values that provided the benefits of empirical estimation without the need for a separate Monte Carlo study. Specifically, Oshima et al. proposed the IPR method, as implemented in the SAS (SAS Institute, 2008) program DIFCUT (Nanda, Oshima, & Gagne, 2006), to derive critical values that are tailored to the characteristics of individual items as well as to the trait scores of focal group examinees. In essence, variances and covariances of estimated focal group item parameters are used to generate 1,000 pairs of parameters for each item that differ only by sampling error. NCDIF statistics are then computed for the respective pairs, ranked in ascending order, and the values above which, say, 1% of cases lie for each item are chosen as the item-specific critical values for DIF detection. Readers interested in the details of the IPR method are referred to Oshima et al. (2006) and Raju, et al. (2009).

To date, only a handful of studies have examined DFIT NCDIF detection using IPR critical values (henceforth, DFIT-IPR), and the results have been mixed. Support for the method was provided in the original paper by Oshima et al. (2006). In addition, Dainis (2008) compared DFIT-IPR performance with dichotomous data to the IRT likelihood ratio (LR) test (Thissen, Steinberg, & Wainer, 1988), logistic regression (Swaminathan & Rogers, 1990), and Mantel–Haenszel (Holland & Thayer, 1988) methods, and she found that with large samples, DFIT-IPR performed as well as the LR test and distinctly better than did the nonparametric alternatives. However, when Raju, et al. (2009) extended the IPR method to polytomous data and compared NCDIF detection with IPR and testwide critical values, which had been recommended by Flowers et al. (1999), the testwide critical values yielded similar or higher power. In addition, DFIT-IPR power was particularly low when DIF was due solely to differences in item discrimination. Furthermore, Clark and LaHuis (2012) compared the efficacy of DFIT-IPR with the LR test using polytomous data and found that the LR test outperformed the DFIT-IPR in most conditions. The superior performance of the LR test was especially apparent in the conditions of DIF due to differences in item discrimination, which is inconsistent with the findings of Bolt (2002) using an empirically based testwide critical value. Consequently, although the DFIT-IPR idea of tailoring critical values to the characteristics of individual items and examinees without requiring an independent simulation has clear merit, more research is needed to understand how factors such as sample size, the direction and magnitude of DIF relative to impact, test length, and linking methods interact to influence performance.

sec.title: The Present Investigation
sec.p: The present study aims to clarify previous research findings and provide a comprehensive assessment of NCDIF detection using DFIT-IPR and testwide critical values for dichotomous and polytomous data. In addition to the factors often manipulated in DIF studies, the authors were especially interested in whether iterative linking (Candell & Drasgow, 1988) would improve DFIT-IPR performance across studied conditions. Iterative linking procedures have been shown to be advantageous at increasing the efficacy of DIF detection for a variety of methods including Mantel–Haenszel (Holland & Thayer, 1988; Navas-Ara & Gomez-Benito, 2002), Lord’s chi-square (Kim & Cohen, 1995; Lautenschlager, Flaherty, & Park, 1994; Park & Lautenschlager, 1990), signed area (Navas-Ara & Gomez-Benito, 2002), and confirmatory factor analysis (Wang, Shih, & Yang, 2009). However, the fact that most DFIT research has utilized single-stage (Barr & Raju, 2003; Escorial & Navas, 2007; Hillemeier, Foster, Heinrichs, & Heier, 2007; Nichol, Krueger, & Iacono, 2007) or two-stage (Flowers et al., 1999; Meade et al., 2007; Oshima et al., 2006; Raju, et al., 2009; Waller, Compas, Hollon, & Beckjord, 2005) linking methods highlights the importance of comparing the ability of these strategies to increase power and reduce Type I error.

A Monte Carlo study was conducted involving more than 1,500 conditions, which were created by combining levels of eight independent variables. The levels of these variables were chosen to span the range of conditions frequently encountered in applied settings. In each condition, 100 replications were performed, and a unique seed was used to generate data in each instance. The details of the study design, computations, and analyses of results are presented in the following.

sec.title: Study Design
sec.p: DFIT NCDIF detection with IPR and testwide critical values was examined in conditions created by manipulating the following independent variables:

list-item.p: Data type: (a) dichotomous and (b) five-option polytomous. Dichotomous data were generated using the three-parameter logistic model (3PLM; Birnbaum, 1968), and polytomous data were generated based on Samejima’s graded response model (SGRM; Samejima, 1969).
Percentage of DIF items: (a) none, (b) 20%, and (c) 33%.

Impact: (a) no impact—reference and focal group data generated using trait scores sampled from independent standard normal distributions; (b) impact against the focal group—focal group data simulated using trait scores sampled from a N(−0.5, 1) distribution, and reference group trait scores sampled from a standard normal distribution; and (c) impact favoring the focal group—focal group trait scores sampled from a N(0.5, 1) distribution, and reference group trait scores sampled from a standard normal distribution.

Type of DIF against the focal group: (a) a only—focal group a parameters for DIF items were decreased by .4 for 3PLM and SGRM, with respect to the reference values; (b) b only—focal group b parameters for DIF items were increased by .7 for 3PLM and by .4 for each b for SGRM, with respect to the reference values; and (c) both a and b.
Test length (total number of items): (a) 15 and (b) 30.

Critical values used for NCDIF detection: (a) IPR-derived critical values corresponding to an alpha of .01 [IPR (.01)], (b) IPR-derived critical values for an alpha of .05 [IPR (.05)], and (c) testwide critical values of .006 for dichotomous data and .016 for polytomous data [Testwide (.01)].

Linking method: (a) single-stage, (b) two-stage, and (c) iterative. Parameters for reference and focal groups were estimated separately and linked using the test characteristic curve method (Stocking & Lord, 1983).

sec.p: As Factor 5 was nested within two levels of Factor 2 and linking conditions were nested within all of the above factors, a total of 1,512 experimental conditions resulted. In each condition, 100 replications of data generation, calibration, linking, and DIF analysis were performed. On each replication, a different seed was used to generate reference and focal group item responses, as well as to generate item parameters for the DFIT-IPR computations.

sec.title: Data Generation
sec.p: In all, 30 sets of 3PLM and SGRM item parameters were selected for dichotomous and polytomous data generation from Stark, Chernyshenko, Chan, Lee, and Drasgow (2001) and Kim and Cohen (1998), respectively. The respective parameters were chosen to cover a range of discrimination and extremity, and ordered to provide reasonable balance across two subsets of items: 1 to 15 and 16 to 30. Items 1 to 15 served as the 15-item tests, and the combined subsets formed the 30-item tests. Because the same item parameters were used to generate data for the reference group in all simulation conditions, these item parameters are shown under the heading “Reference Group” in Tables 1 and 2.

caption.p: Generating Item Parameters in Dichotomous a and b DIF Conditions

fn.p: Note: DIF = differential item functioning; Avg. NCDIF = averaged noncompensatory DIF value for each DIF item. The 15-item tests were created using Items 1 to 15 of the 30-item measures. In the no DIF conditions, the same item parameters were used to generate response data for reference and focal groups. In the 20% and 33% both a and b DIF conditions, focal group parameters for additional items were manipulated as shown. For a only and b only DIF conditions, only the a or b parameters from the displayed focal group were used.

caption.p: Generating Item Parameters in Polytomous a and b DIF Conditions

fn.p: Note: DIF = differential item functioning; Avg. NCDIF = averaged noncompensatory DIF value for each DIF item. The 15-item tests were created using Items 1 to 15 of the 30-item measures. In the no DIF conditions, the same item parameters were used to generate response data for reference and focal groups. In the 20% and 33% both a and b DIF conditions, focal group parameters for additional items were manipulated as shown. For a only and b only DIF conditions, only the a or b parameters from the displayed focal group were used.

sec.p: In no DIF conditions, focal group responses were generated using the reference group item parameters. In DIF conditions, focal group item parameters were shifted on selected items, as described under the section “Study Design” (Point 4). As can be seen under the heading “Focal Group” in Tables 1 and 2, the focal group parameters were shifted on Items 4, 7, 13, 19, 22, and 28 in the “20% DIF” conditions and additionally on Items 2, 10, 17, and 25 in the “33% DIF” conditions. To illustrate the effects of the parameter shifts, items manipulated to produce DIF against the focal group in the both a and b conditions are presented. For conditions of a only and b only DIF, the reference group parameters are utilized for the b and a parameters, respectively. The amount of DIF produced by these shifts, averaged across the a only, b only, and both a and b conditions, is shown in the respective tables under the heading “Avg. NCDIF.”

Using the item parameters presented in Tables 1 and 2, in conjunction with person parameters sampled from the distributions specified under the section “Study Design” (Point 3), dichotomous reference and focal group response data were generated using the 3PLGEN computer program (Stark, 2000), and polytomous response data were generated using the SGRGEN computer program (Stark, 1999). Different seeds were used to generate reference and focal group data on each replication in each experimental condition.

sec.title: Parameter Estimation, Linking, and DIF Computations
sec.p: BILOG-MG3 (Zimowski, Muraki, Mislevy, & Bock, 2002) was used to estimate parameters in dichotomous conditions, and PARSCALE (Muraki & Bock, 1997) was used to estimate parameters in polytomous conditions because these programs provide the item parameter covariances necessary for DFIT-IPR analyses. Parameter estimation convergence diagnostics were tracked across replications as an alert to potential problems and the need to adjust the number of valid replications accordingly when computing power and Type I error.

Linking of reference and focal group parameter estimates was accomplished with the POLYST computer program (Kim & Kolen, 2003) based on the test characteristic curve method (Stocking & Lord, 1983). DFIT8 (Raju, Oshima, & Wolach, 2009) was used to perform the DFIT-IPR analyses, and a C++ program was written to perform DFIT analyses using NCDIF testwide critical values. (The NCDIF values from this program were verified for accuracy before this simulation by comparing results with the output from DFIT8 and DIFCUT; Nanda et al., 2006.) DIF results were computed using testwide and IPR critical values corresponding to a nominal alpha of .01 via single-stage, two-stage, and iterative linking. Specifically, reference and focal group metrics were initially linked using all items, and DIF statistics were computed; these findings were recorded as the single-stage linking results. Next, items identified as DIF-free at the end of stage one were used to relink the metrics, and a second DIF analysis was performed to obtain the two-stage linking results. This process of linking, using only items identified as DIF-free, followed by a DIF analysis, continued until the same results were obtained on consecutive trials; the findings from this last iteration of the process were reported for iterative linking. Note that because the authors knew little about IPR power and the data were readily available, they also tracked DFIT-IPR results based on a nominal alpha of .05.

The overall process of data generation, parameter estimation, linking, DIF detection, and repetition as needed for two-stage and iterative linking was coordinated by a C++ program that made all necessary software calls, managed data flow, and tracked convergence diagnostics, power, and Type I error across replications. On completion of the simulation, power results were analyzed using ANOVA.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A detailed examination of the C++ simulation program output indicated that item parameters for extreme response options could not be estimated on more than half of the replications in polytomous conditions where impact acted against the focal group in concert with increases in item extremity. These 24 conditions were, thus, excluded from further analysis, and the results for the remaining 1,488 conditions were examined using factorial ANOVA involving up to three-way interactions.

Table 3 presents the ANOVA results for the combined effects of the independent variables on power, along with interactions that accounted for at least 1% of the variance. Power refers to the proportion of DIF items that were correctly identified as DIF across the replications in a given condition. The ω2 effect size statistics on the right side of the table clearly indicate that the largest effect on power was the type of DIF simulated followed, as a distant second, by the type of critical value used for NCDIF detection. The other independent variables and interactions had significant but smaller effects, with slight improvements in DIF detection associated with larger sample size and test length, and lower power associated with higher percentages of DIF items. Impact did not have a major effect on performance, and although iterative linking did not provide much benefit in terms of power, inspection of the detailed results in the tables that follow revealed that two-stage and iterative linking were far more effective than single-stage linking in controlling Type I error.

caption.p: ANOVA Results for the Effects of Independent Variables and Nontrivial Interactions on Power

fn.p: Note: ω2 = proportion of variance accounted for by the independent variable(s); dfB = degrees of freedom between; DIF = differential item functioning. For all effects, degrees of freedom within = 970.

sec.p: Tables 4 and 5 present the detailed results for dichotomous conditions involving samples of 500 and 1,000, respectively. As can be seen in the tables, power was generally high in the b only DIF conditions, low in the a only DIF conditions, and quite variable in the both a and b DIF conditions. There was no obvious improvement in power associated with larger sample size, and only small improvements in power resulted from two-stage or iterative linking. However, two-stage and iterative linking dramatically reduced Type I error for the testwide and IPR critical values. For example, the last row in Table 4 indicates that Type I errors in the Testwide (.01) condition dropped from .38 (single-stage) to .07 (two-stage) to .03 (iterative). Type I error in the same IPR (.01) condition dropped from .21 (single-stage) to .05 (two-stage) to .02 (iterative). Overall, the Testwide (.01) critical value yielded higher power than the IPR critical values, and IPR (.01) produced slightly better Type I errors given the same linking method. The only glaring exceptions were when DIF was simulated on 33% of the items by shifting a and b parameters (see the last three rows of Table 5). Using the Testwide (.01) critical value with iterative linking yielded power in the .9 range with no Type I errors, whereas IPR (.01) yielded power ranging from .43 to .78 with Type I errors varying from .06 to .14. Clearly, IPR performance was adversely influenced by the joint effect of impact and DIF against the focal group when a high percentage of items was simulated as DIF.

caption.p: Power and Type I Error Rates for Testwide and IPR Critical Values in Dichotomous Conditions With N = 500

fn.p: Note: IPR = item parameter replication; N = 500 for reference and focal groups; 1-Stage = single-stage linking; 2-Stage = two-stage linking; Iterative = iterative linking; DIF = differential item functioning; Length = number of items in test; %DIF = percentage of items manipulated to create DIF against the focal group; Impact = −0.5 (one-half SD of impact against the focal group), Impact = +0.5 (one-half SD of impact favoring the focal group); P = power; T1E = Type I error.

caption.p: Power and Type I Error Rates for Testwide and IPR Critical Values in Dichotomous Conditions With N = 1,000

fn.p: Note: IPR = item parameter replication; N = 1,000 for reference and focal groups; 1-Stage = single-stage linking; 2-Stage = two-stage linking; Iterative = iterative linking; DIF = differential item functioning; Length = number of items in test; %DIF = percentage of items manipulated to create DIF against the focal group; Impact = −0.5 (one-half SD of impact against the focal group), Impact = +0.5 (one-half SD of impact favoring the focal group); P = power; T1E = Type I error.

sec.p: Tables 6 and 7 present the power and Type I error results for the N = 500 and N = 1,000 polytomous conditions. The “x” entries indicate the cells that were dropped due to the parameter estimation problems mentioned above. Overall, the pattern of results is fairly similar to what was observed in the dichotomous conditions. Power was highest for testwide and IPR critical values in the b only conditions and lowest in the a only conditions, and there was no global improvement associated with larger sample size or test length. Power to detect DIF due to differences in discrimination was higher for Testwide (.01) in polytomous conditions than in dichotomous conditions, but with the small sample, Type I error was also inflated with values in the .10 to .18 range—a finding that is consistent with results reported by Meade et al. (2007).

caption.p: Power and Type I Error Rates for Testwide and IPR Critical Values in Polytomous Conditions With N = 500

fn.p: Note: IPR = item parameter replication; N = 500 for reference and focal groups; 1-Stage = single-stage linking; 2-Stage = two-stage linking; Iterative = iterative linking; DIF = differential item functioning; Length = number of items in test; %DIF = percentage of items manipulated to create DIF against the focal group; Impact = −0.5 (one-half SD of impact against the focal group), Impact = +0.5 (one-half SD of impact favoring the focal group); P = power; T1E = Type I error.

caption.p: Power and Type I Error Rates for Testwide and IPR Critical Values in Polytomous Conditions With N = 1,000

fn.p: Note: IPR = item parameter replication; N = 1,000 for reference and focal groups; 1-Stage = single-stage linking; 2-Stage = two-stage linking; Iterative = iterative linking; DIF = differential item functioning; Length = number of items in test; %DIF = percentage of items manipulated to create DIF against the focal group; Impact = −0.5 (one-half SD of impact against the focal group), Impact = +0.5 (one-half SD of impact favoring the focal group); P = power; T1E = Type I error.

sec.p: In contrast, although IPR provided excellent control of Type I error when combined with iterative linking, power declined drastically in polytomous conditions, even relative to the modest values that were observed with dichotomous data. For example, in one N = 500 polytomous condition involving iterative linking, IPR (.01) showed a power of zero, and the highest observed value was just .03. Increasing the sample size to 1,000 provided only marginal improvement with a resulting maximum of .15.

Finally, IPR and testwide critical values provided near-perfect detection of b only and both a and b DIF when used in conjunction with two-stage and iterative linking in the large-sample polytomous conditions. Both methods improved power relative to single-stage linking, but the benefits of iterative linking are most evident when it comes to Type I errors. In general, higher percentages of DIF items were associated with lower power and higher Type I errors throughout this study, but iterative linking ameliorated this problem somewhat. As can be seen in the last row of Table 7, the Type I error was .71 for Testwide (.01) with single-stage linking, .07 with two-stage, and .01 with iterative linking, and the corresponding values for IPR (.01) were .41, .02, and .00, respectively. This is important, for example, when working with new measures, such as a scale that has been recently translated into a different language. The unnecessary loss of items due to spurious DIF detection can be mitigated by simply performing an additional stage of linking and DIF analysis, and, if feasible, iterative linking should be performed because it will almost certainly provide the best Type I error control, as is apparent in Tables 4 through 7.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The primary goal of this study was to compare the efficacy of DFIT DIF detection using testwide critical values recommended for dichotomous (3PLM) and five-option polytomous (SGRM) response data (Flowers et al., 1999) with item-specific critical values obtained using the IPR method (Oshima et al., 2006). This study is the first to compare DFIT-IPR-based DIF detection using different alpha levels in conjunction with a large array of factors that included test length, impact, types and percentages of DIF items, number of linking stages, data types, and sample size.

The results indicated that although the IPR method has the potential to enhance DIF detection by tailoring critical values to individual item properties, the testwide recommendations for dichotomous data produced as good or better results in a wide range of conditions when considering the trade-off between sensitivity to DIF and Type I error. With polytomous data, the use of IPR-derived critical values produced low power to detect differences in item discrimination, and, for the testwide critical value, the increase in power compared with IPR results corresponded with an increase in Type I error for small-sample size conditions. There was a consistent trade-off between power and Type I error when comparing testwide and IPR-derived critical values. IPR-derived critical values were less likely to result in items being incorrectly flagged as DIF, but this came at the expense of power. The low power to detect differences in item discrimination using DFIT-IPR mirrors the findings of Clark and LaHuis (2012) for the small and large magnitude of DIF conditions, despite the fact that they used only the designated (known) non-DIF items for linking.

The idea of deriving testwide critical values by simulating and analyzing large numbers of non-DIF items, and finding the values above which proportions of observations fall is intuitive and fairly effective. Although it would be cumbersome to develop precise guidelines for the many IRT models and data types that have not yet been explored, the process illustrated by Flowers et al. (1999) produced excellent results in most of the conditions examined here, especially when combined with iterative linking. High power and low Type I error were observed across dichotomous and polytomous conditions when two-stage or iterative linking was performed, but Type I error values as high as .32 and .71 were still observed in the large-sample dichotomous and polytomous Testwide (.01) conditions, respectively, when single-stage linking was used. IPR (.01) and IPR (.05) reduced Type I error slightly, but the sensitivity to DIF also diminished accordingly. Considering the ease with which two-stage and iterative linking can be performed, and the ensuing improvements in power and Type I error, the benefits of these alternatives to single-stage linking cannot be overstated.

The IPR method for obtaining critical values for DIF detection requires item parameter estimates and their covariances. Although, in principle, estimates from either the reference or focal group can be used, the results will differ somewhat due to the effects of sample characteristics on estimation accuracy (see Blitz & Morris, 2011). In addition, the method (computer program) used to estimate covariances can also have a substantial effect on IPR performance. Before this study was conducted, DFIT-IPR DIF detection for polytomous data using covariance estimates provided by PARSCALE was compared with those provided by a FORTRAN program developed by Fortmann-Johnson (2008). Surprisingly, although the covariance estimates differed only slightly, the effects on Type I error were substantial in many cases. This may account for the high Type I error results in conditions involving unequal sample sizes, shown in Clark and LaHuis (2012). It is, therefore, important to consider these practical matters when choosing between IPR and testwide approaches. It may be the case that recent advances by Blitz and Morris (2011) will obviate these concerns.

As is always the case, the study is not without limitations. Despite examining a vast number of experimental conditions, some issues regarding DFIT NCDIF analyses were not explored here, and the hope is that researchers will pursue these issues in future studies. The first issue is the arbitrary decision to link the reference group to the focal group rather than vice versa, and to use focal group trait scores, rather than reference group trait scores, for DFIT computations. The procedure followed here was advocated by Raju et al. (1995), but it is an open question as to whether such basic decisions have a measurable effect on the outcomes of DFIT analyses. One might also explore whether integrating over an assumed ability density or a posterior distribution when computing true score functions would produce better results than summations involving focal group theta hats.

The process by which the IPR method operates suggests that it would provide critical values tailored to a specified alpha while maintaining commensurate levels of power. However, the current results indicate otherwise, indicating that additional factors may be interfering with the procedure’s accuracy. Researchers should explore whether difficulties commonly encountered when estimating item variance and covariance matrices (Thissen & Wainer, 1982) influence the accuracy of IPR-derived critical values. Although the DFIT-IPR method and LR test are area difference methods, the fact that the LR test does not require the use of variance–covariance matrices may account for its overall superior performance under the conditions studied by Clark and LaHuis (2012). Future research may examine the influence of factors such as estimation procedure and prior distributions, such as those explored by Kim (2007), on DFIT-IPR DIF detection. These findings might be helpful in improving the IPR methodology and eliminating the sampling anomalies mentioned by Oshima et al. (2006), which require corrective action. Alternatively, testwide critical values for various alpha levels might be derived as a function of sample size to produce more refined guidelines for practitioners, and adjustments for proportions of items having different numbers of response categories within a test due to infrequent endorsement deserve consideration. Because of the low power found in the small-sample conditions, the authors also suggest that future research investigate the performance of DFIT using samples of fewer than 500, and focal and reference groups of different size.

In summary, the DFIT method is an attractive procedure for DIF detection because it can be applied readily with a wide variety of IRT models. Although the IPR method for obtaining critical values might eventually become industry standard because the computations for various models can be built right into the software packages, it is clearly premature to dismiss the intuitive testwide procedure. The fact that values derived in previous studies worked as well as they did across the wide range of conditions examined here is a testament to its merit. A fruitful avenue of research might therefore be to expand the testwide recommendations to account for broad differences in sample size, and the range of dominance and ideal point models garnering the interest of applied researchers.
